newsitem.title: USA: Florida governor would prefer tobacco settlement.
newsitem.headline: Florida governor would prefer tobacco settlement.

text.p: Florida Gov. Lawton Chiles said Tuesday the state was prepared to return to the table and resume good-faith mediation with tobacco companies that are the target of Florida's $1 billion lawsuit.

"We're prepared to follow the Court's order to return to the table and resume good-faith mediation with the tobacco giants," Chiles said in a statement issued on a ruling on the Florida suit by Palm Beach County Circuit Judge Harold Cohen. "I've always preferred a settlement that pays for the damage our taxpayers have shouldered and protects our children over a drawn-out court battle."

Cohen's ruling stripped 15 of 18 counts from the lawsuit, which seeks reimbursement of what Chiles said was $420 million per year in Medicaid payments for treatment of tobacco-related illnesses in Florida.
Among other things, Cohen's ruling barred Florida from seeking reimbursement for Medicaid expenses before 1994. The law under which Florida is suing the industry was passed in 1994.
Earlier Tuesday, Chiles had told reporters in Tallahassee that Cohen's ruling had preserved the most important points of the suit.
